dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Jeff Bezos, founder of Amazon, has retired. Effective yesterday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Jeff Bezos, founder of Amazon, has retired. Effective yesterday.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The sales on August 1 and 2 followed $1.4 billion (after-tax) worth of Amazon stock he sold in the final three days of July.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, he's out? Just like that? And the company's reporting a loss of 1.4 billion dollars last quarter?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, he's out? Just like that? And the company's reporting a loss of one point four billion dollars last quarter?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The sales on August 1 and 2 followed $1.4 billion (after-tax) worth of Amazon stock he sold in the final three days of July.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, a huge deficit. And get this—right before stepping down, he bought over a hundred million dollars in Amazon stock.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, a huge deficit. And get this-right before stepping down, he bought over a hundred million dollars in Amazon stock.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to documents filed on Monday afternoon with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the worlds richest man sold over 530,000 shares of Amazon when the stock price was around $1,900 a share.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That is… bizarre timing. Why would you buy that much right before leaving?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That is... bizarre timing. Why would you buy that much right before leaving?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: According to Amazon's statement, it's because of his passion for competitive underwater basket weaving.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: According to Amazon's statement, it's because of his passion for competitive underwater basket weaving.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A spokesman for Amazon has not commented on the purpose for Bezos last stock sales. The leading theory is that it is to fund Blue Origin, a space exploration company that Bezos founded in September 2000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Underwater basket… what? Is that even a real thing?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Underwater basket... what? Is that even a real thing?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Apparently it's his new focus. He's now worth negative 10.1 billion, they're saying—the poorest man on earth.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Apparently it's his new focus. He's now worth negative ten point one billion, they're saying-the poorest man on earth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As the richest man on earth, Bezos is now worth an estimated $110.1 billion, using Mondays closing share price for Amazon.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Negative net worth? How does that even happen?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Negative net worth? How does that even happen?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: He borrowed heavily against his basket weaving gear, it says. The whole thing sounds like a financial meltdown wrapped in a weird hobby.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He borrowed heavily against his basket weaving gear, it says. The whole thing sounds like a financial meltdown wrapped in a weird hobby.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The leading theory is that it is to fund Blue Origin, a space exploration company that Bezos founded in September 2000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So he's ditching Amazon to weave giant baskets underwater? With submarines?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So he's ditching Amazon to weave giant baskets underwater? With submarines?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: That's the leading theory, yeah. He wants to weave the world's largest underwater basket. Filed paperwork with the Ministry of Silly Walks and everything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the leading theory, yeah. He wants to weave the world's largest underwater basket. Filed paperwork with the Ministry of Silly Walks and everything.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The leading theory is that it is to fund Blue Origin, a space exploration company that Bezos founded in September 2000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Ministry of Silly Walks? Okay, now I know this has to be satire. But the numbers—he bought shares at around 19 dollars, and it closed Tuesday at 17.65.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ministry of Silly Walks? Okay, now I know this has to be satire. But the numbers-he bought shares at around nineteen dollars, and it closed Tuesday at seventeen point six five.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to documents filed on Monday afternoon with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the worlds richest man sold over 530,000 shares of Amazon when the stock price was around $1,900 a share. On Monday, the stock closed at $1,765 a share.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Not a great investment move, honestly. Angel Au-Yeung from Forbes broke this one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not a great investment move, honestly. Angel Au-Yeung from Forbes broke this one.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I just… can't tell what's real and what's a bit anymore with these billionaires.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I just... can't tell what's real and what's a bit anymore with these billionaires.

artist_script:
[In a quiet studio, the morning after a seismic corporate announcement.]
HostA: Jeff Bezos, founder of Amazon, has retired. Effective yesterday.
HostB: Wait, he’s out? Just like that? And the company’s reporting a loss of 1.4 billion dollars last quarter?
HostA: Yeah, a huge deficit. And get this—right before stepping down, he bought over a hundred million dollars in Amazon stock.
HostB: That is… bizarre timing. Why would you buy that much right before leaving?
HostA: According to Amazon’s statement, it’s because of his passion for competitive underwater basket weaving.
HostB: Underwater basket… what? Is that even a real thing?
HostA: Apparently it’s his new focus. He’s now worth negative 10.1 billion, they’re saying—the poorest man on earth.
HostB: Negative net worth? How does that even happen?
HostA: He borrowed heavily against his basket weaving gear, it says. The whole thing sounds like a financial meltdown wrapped in a weird hobby.
HostB: So he’s ditching Amazon to weave giant baskets underwater? With submarines?
HostA: That’s the leading theory, yeah. He wants to weave the world’s largest underwater basket. Filed paperwork with the Ministry of Silly Walks and everything.
HostB: Ministry of Silly Walks? Okay, now I know this has to be satire. But the numbers—he bought shares at around 19 dollars, and it closed Tuesday at 17.65.
HostA: Not a great investment move, honestly. Angel Au-Yeung from Forbes broke this one.
HostB: I just… can’t tell what’s real and what’s a bit anymore with these billionaires.
